items.title: Australia news live: neo-Nazi Thomas Sewell arrested outside Melbourne court after crashing Jacinta Allan press conference
items.standfirst: Follow today’s news liveJacinta Allan says she is not afraid of neo-Nazi ‘goons’ after press conference gatecrashedGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastRallies ‘deeply unsettling for many Australians’: Mark ButlerMark Butler is continuing his media rounds and has moved across to ABC News Breakfast.I think these rallies were deeply unsettling for many Australians. For most Australians who saw from that rally, a message of division, intolerance and in some cases, violence - including violence against police.I think what we want to do from a federal government [point of view] is just reinforce the importance of social cohesion – the importance of us being a really successful multicultural community with all of the benefits.These new, evolving, technologies require and a new, proactive, approach to harm prevention– and we’ll work closely with industry to achieve this.While this move won’t eliminate the problem of abusive technology in one fell swoop, alongside existing laws and our world-leading online safety reforms, it will make a real difference in protecting Australians. Continue reading...

For most Australians who saw from that rally, a message of division, intolerance and in some cases, violence - including violence against police.I think what we want to do from a federal government [point of view] is just reinforce the importance of social cohesion – the importance of us being a really successful multicultural community with all of the benefits.These new, evolving, technologies require and a new, proactive, approach to harm prevention– and we’ll work closely with industry to achieve this.While this move won’t eliminate the problem of abusive technology in one fell swoop, alongside existing laws and our world-leading online safety reforms, it will make a real difference in protecting Australians. items.title: Neo-Nazi Thomas Sewell arrested outside court
items.standfirst: Self-proclaimed neo-Nazi Thomas Sewell has been arrested outside court in Melbourne.
items.content: Self-proclaimed neo-Nazi Thomas Sewell has been arrested outside court in Melbourne.

items.title: Neo-Nazi arrested outside court hours after crashing media conference
items.standfirst: The Victorian premier has hit back after copping an expletive laden tirade from neo-Nazi leader Thomas Sewell.
items.content: Self-proclaimed neo-Nazi Thomas Sewell has been arrested outside a Melbourne court hours after he crashed Victorian Premier Jacinta Allan's press conference.Sewell was taken into custody out the front of Melbourne Magistrates' Court, where he was representing himself on a number of charges, including intimidating a police officer, following Sunday's anti-immigration march.Exclusive 9News vision shows Sewell being arrested by several police officers about 3.20pm.READ MORE: Police descend on accused gunman Dezi Freeman's propertyVictoria Police confirmed that detectives from the Melbourne Crime Investigation Unit attended Melbourne Magistrates Court about 3.20pm and arrested three men."Officers arrested a 32-year-old man from Balwyn, a 23-year-old man from Mooroolbark and a 20-year-old man from Ardeer," a spokesperson said."They are being interviewed in relation to an ongoing investigation into alleged assaults in King's Domain about 5pm on 31 August."No charges relating to the arrest have been made yet.9News understands today's arrest is in relation to an incident on Sunday where white supremacists stormed a First Nations camp.Sewell's arrest comes hours after he gatecrashed Allan's press conference, where he yelled at the premier over his right to protest.Allan was with Treasurer Jaclyn Symes in North Melbourne when Sewell arrived."Why don't Australians have the right to protest?" Sewell could be heard saying.READ MORE: 'Gutless' attack by neo-Nazis on sacred Indigenous site slammed"Why do you want to ban us from protesting? Shouldn't we have the right to speak in our own country?" Sewell was held back by security as Allan and Symes quickly left.Sewell was heard telling security, "You don't have the right to put your hands on me".READ MORE: Fears the country's most wanted man is 'getting help'"We're going to take this country back from politicians like you," he said to Allan.Sewell left the scene after Allan, walking away on foot."Victoria Police is aware of an incident at a media stand-up in North Melbourne this morning where a man attended and was verbally abusive towards the premier," a police spokesperson said."The premier's security team intervened to ensure the safety of everyone present and the man left shortly after."Allan also issued a statement, saying she was "unharmed and undeterred".She said it was a "badge of honour" to earn the ire of Nazis."But this isn't about me. It's about all the other people in the community who Nazis target - like multicultural people, LGBTIQA+ people, First Peoples, and Jews," she said in the written statement."They're the Victorians who are on my mind right now, and they're the Victorians who our anti-hate laws will protect when they come into force later this month."The new legislation will strengthen Victoria's existing vilification laws, and make it a criminal offence to incite hate or threaten harm based on a protected attribute."We know how these goons operate. They whip up fear to divide our society. They will fail," Allan said of Sewell."Because Victorians are fair, and our values are strong."The New Zealand-born white nationalist figure recently made a speech to the crowd at the anti-immigration March For Australia rally in Melbourne on Sunday.In his tirade at the press conference, Sewell also incorrectly claimed 50,000 people attended that rally.On Sunday, he was also seen in a crowd that allegedly attacked an Indigenous encampment, Camp Sovereignty, after splitting off from the main rally.Police are investigating the incident, which Police Minister Andrew Carbines labelled "gutless".DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

items.title: Labor facing backlash over plans to curb access to government information
items.standfirst: Changes announced by Michelle Rowland include new charges for FoI requests as well as tougher rules related to cabinet confidentialityFollow our Australia news live blog for latest updatesGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastLabor is facing a backlash over plans to dramatically curb access to government documents under freedom of information rules, with the Coalition and crossbench signalling proposed changes will struggle to pass parliament.The attorney general, Michelle Rowland, has announced the biggest changes to transparency rules in more than a decade, including new charges for freedom of information requests to government departments and ministers, as well as tougher rules related to cabinet confidentiality. Continue reading...

items.title: Faruqi on March for Australia: racism has been 'legitimised' by media and politicians – video
items.standfirst: Speaking in the Senate while moving a motion for debate on social cohesion, Greens senator Mehreen Faruqi said the far right had been 'emboldened' and was now 'on the move', saying racism has been 'legitimised' and 'normalised' by media and politicians. Faruqi said anti-immigration rallies over the weekend should be a 'wake-up call', and accused other politicians of having downplayed or fuelled racism. The senator also read out some of the abusive and violent letters that she said she receives weekly. 'Migrants like me have been told repeatedly to put up, shut up or go back to where I come from,' Faruqi saidNeo-Nazis and politicians among protesters at anti-immigration March for Australia rallies Continue reading...
items.content: Speaking in the Senate while moving a motion for debate on social cohesion, Greens senator Mehreen Faruqi said the far right had been 'emboldened' and was now 'on the move', saying racism has been 'legitimised' and 'normalised' by media and politicians. Faruqi said anti-immigration rallies over the weekend should be a 'wake-up call', and accused other politicians of having downplayed or fuelled racism. The senator also read out some of the abusive and violent letters that she said she receives weekly. 'Migrants like me have been told repeatedly to put up, shut up or go back to where I come from,' Faruqi saidNeo-Nazis and politicians among protesters at anti-immigration March for Australia rallies Continue reading...

clusters.title: Former prosecutor in firing line during Tony Mokbel appeal
clusters.neutral_headline: Former Prosecutor's Role Questioned in Mokbel Appeal

items.title: Former prosecutor in firing line during Tony Mokbel appeal
items.standfirst: A former prosecutor had a duty to disclose barrister Nicola Gobbo was a police informer as early as June 2012, lawyers for Tony Mokbel argued.
items.content: A former prosecutor had a duty to disclose barrister Nicola Gobbo was a police informer as early as June 2012, lawyers for Tony Mokbel argued.

items.title: Prosecutor should have said lawyer was police informer, Mokbel's legal team argues
items.standfirst: A former director of public prosecutions had a duty to disclose barrister Nicola Gobbo was a police informer as early as June 2012, lawyers for Tony Mokbel have argued.
items.content: A former director of public prosecutions had a duty to disclose barrister Nicola Gobbo was a police informer as early as June 2012, lawyers for Tony Mokbel have argued.The kingpin fronted the Victorian Court of Appeal today for the first day of his long-awaited appeal against drug trafficking and importation convictions.Mokbel, who was released on bail in April, claims he suffered a miscarriage of justice because he was represented by Gobbo while she was a police informer.READ MORE: Leading genocide scholars say Israel committing genocide in GazaThe then-barrister was registered as a Victoria Police informer from 2005 to 2009 and was acting as Mokbel's lawyer for four years before he fled to Greece in 2006.She continued to advise him when he was extradited to Melbourne in 2008.Mokbel pleaded guilty to two counts of trafficking a drug of dependence for trafficking MDMA and methamphetamine in April 2011 after striking a deal with prosecutors.He did not find out about Gobbo's status as an informer until the High Court lifted gag orders in 2018.In pre-appeal rulings, NSW Supreme Court Justice Elizabeth Fullerton found former director of public prosecutions and current Victorian judge John Champion was told in June 2012 that Gobbo was a registered informer.Justice Fullerton was also satisfied Justice Champion knew Victoria Police held concerns about the integrity of Gobbo's clients' convictions at the time of the June meeting.READ MORE: Australia issues travel warning for popular tourist destination amid unrestBut Justice Fullerton ruled it was only after another meeting in September 2012 that Justice Champion had an obligation to disclose Gobbo's status to the court.Today, Mokbel's barrister Julie Condon KC argued Justice Fullerton should have found Justice Champion breached his duty of disclosure as early as June 1, 2012."The director ... was obliged to at the very least notify this court that there was a pressing matter, albeit not capable of overt disclosure, that had come into his direct knowledge," Condon told the Court of Appeal."It was of such a nature that the director couldn't sit back and do nothing - which is, in effect, what he did."DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

ai_summary: Lawyers for Tony Mokbel argued a prosecutor had a duty.
The duty was to disclose barrister Nicola Gobbo as an informer.
The disclosure should have happened as early as June 2012.
A former director of public prosecutions is implicated.
The legal team is arguing the prosecutor's actions.

ai_summary: Ben Ayres, 44, experienced a heart attack after finishing a gym workout.
